messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Digest Number 208 CHEMISTRY
messages.msgSnippet: ... life...WHY? The portions were too small is a hypothesis. So try bigger portions. WHY does this work better? or does it? What happens if you substitute
messages.messageBody:
> > WHY didn't the stuff work?

:) That is a chemistry question!! Science in
life...WHY? The portions were too small is a
hypothesis. So try bigger portions. WHY does this work
better? or does it? What happens if you substitute
something for something else? WHY?

Sharon of the Swamp

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Questions about unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/6/02 11:46:03 AM, cloister@earthlink.net writes:  the 1960 s
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/6/02 11:46:03 AM, cloister@... writes:

<< How long has this unschooling as it is today been around. >>

the 1960's

<<It is my understanding that there is no real way to define it.>>

There are lots of descriptions, but not a one single official definition.
There are many things which are NOT unschooling, and lots that are. Mostly
it's a way of looking at learning, and a changing of priorities and
awarenesses.

<<It is my understanding that unschooling is when you allow the children to
lead. >>

That's too simple a description. If you really want to understand
unschooling from the point of view of many families who are committed to it,
go to www.unschooling.com and read the archives and the message boards.

<<How does it translates when you have a child who has an area that they don't
wish to do because to them it is hard. Such as writing or math.>>

These things are discussed at length at unschooling.com, and so you could go
and read what's already written.

<<I am sure that all of us want the best for our children.
The best to me means is college and hopefully a 4 year college after high
school. How does this unschooling works when there are S.A. T. scores are
going to matter along with G. P. A. and ton of other things.>>

Also already discussed.

This list is not really for the purpose of intro to unschooling, sorry.
There's an assumption that people here have read some John Holt or are
unschoolers already.

[Note for others on the list who might wonder why I'm being short about this:
cloister@... on another list I was on, and I'm guessing that's
why she or he is here now with beginner questions.]

Sandra

messages.subject: Questions about unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: How long has this unschooling as it is today been around. What I mean is as it is happening in home schooling. It is my understanding that there is no real way
messages.messageBody:
How long has this unschooling as it is today been around.

What I mean is as it is happening in home schooling.

It is my understanding that there is no real way to define it.

It is my understanding that unschooling is when you allow the children to
lead.

I also think that a lot book work would not be part of the setting of
unschooling. Nor would tests. Is this wrong?

How does it translates when you have a child who has an area that they don't
wish to do because to them it is hard. Such as writing or math.

I am sure that all of us want the best for our children.
The best to me means is college and hopefully a 4 year college after high
school. How does this unschooling works when there are S.A. T. scores are
going to matter along with G. P. A. and ton of other things.

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Digest Number 208
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 2/6/2002 9:59:13 AM Pacific Standard Time, ... Because it is micro chemistry - made to be little bitty amounts of stuff - very
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 2/6/2002 9:59:13 AM Pacific Standard Time,
AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com writes:


> WHY didn't the stuff work?

Because it is "micro" chemistry - made to be little bitty amounts of stuff -
very disappointing. We have the huge big Smithsonian set and we lost interest
fast.

--pam
